column2: we have got to distinguish between the 19 landings out of 20 and the one landing out of 20. The obligation is to control and supervise one landing out of 20 to enable the other 19 to be brought to the factories and weighed or weighed on the pier-side weighing device
column3: which is owned by the industry. Therefore
column4: there is an option to weigh the 19 out of 20 in the factories or on the pier-side weighing device. On the one in 20 whose weighing we need to supervise
column5: there are currently two options open to a master landing in Killybegs. column6: the tanker is brought back to the weighbridge and weighed again. One weight is subtracted from the other and the result is the weight of the fish in the tanker. The second option open to the master or operator is to discharge into an empty tanker that is the pre-weighed. The fish are pumped into it with the water they were originally in. It is up to the operator to take off as much water as deemed possible without interfering with the quality of the fish. The weight is then determined on the weighbridge
column7: and that is recorded as the official weight of the fish.

column2: SFPA
column3: is acting ultra vires in how it is dealing with this. Suddenly
column4: the European Commission started to share the authority's concerns. Why was that not addressed? Why is there another barrier to resolving the problems at Killybegs? Why was that not implemented? column5: which is very serious. The SFPA has not sought to regularise it
column6: take control of the weighing system
column7: and demonstrate clearly to all concerned parties that it is an independent system. It could demonstrate it is the best regulator in Europe and good at its job
column8: so there is nothing for the European Commission to worry about. It could have CCTV cameras and unannounced inspections
column9: with a level of oversight that is unprecedented in any other industry in Ireland or throughout Europe. column2: the owners of the machines said they were not prepared to enter into a lease arrangement. We have not heard anything different in the meantime. It was the court's view that we were acting ultra vires by not permitting the pier-side weighing device. It was subsequently permitted and we were in full compliance with the judgment of the court.

column1: #PadraigMacLochlainn	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-party	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-dob	unknown-#PadraigMacLochlainn-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-05-18 00:00:00	Weighing of Fisheries Products: Discussion	194	I have here a copy of correspondence sent to Mr. Hayes on 5 May from the SFPA consultative committee
column2: which exists under the same legislation as the SFPA. It has grave concerns about how this has been handled and the lack of consultation with it. It asks
column3: if the ownership of the flow scales on the pier in Killybegs is transferred to systems not operated or owned by the industry
column4: whether the SFPA can meet the requirements of the interim control plan. In all my talks and discussions with the industry
column5: as is my responsibility as a Deputy for Donegal and Sinn Féin spokesperson on fisheries
column6: it has been made clear to me that it does not want to have ownership of this weighing system. It wants a solution. I will put this to Mr. Hayes and Dr. O'Mahony. I think it does it well and so does the European Union. I understand that the compliance level in Ireland is 98%. We are not a rogue state or the Wild West. column7: which the industry accepts and was needed to deal with the concerns about illegal practices that may have taken place in the past. In 2022
column8: the SFPA's level of oversight in Killybegs is incredible. Why can it not take possession or find some way for those scales to go into independent possession to address everybody's concerns? Will the witnesses get to the crux of that issue?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-05-18 00:00:00	Weighing of Fisheries Products: Discussion	292	I will answer the question about surrealism. No
column2: this is not surreal. It is not rocket science; it is about weighing fish and figuring out how much fish are landed. It should not be rocket science. The fact that we are having a discussion about it is not surreal. This is the backbone of fishery control. The whole point of giving a quantitative
column3: capped amount of fish that fishermen can catch is that it needs a backbone. This is about giving that backbone. There is nothing surreal about that. I am not sure where the confusion is in option 1
column4: but it is option 1 because it is our recommended option. We believe it will give a very accurate weight and absolute control over quality. There is no limit to the amount of water one could have. The big issue with option 1 is that the water is weighed and is in the tanker before the fish arrive in the tanker. Let us say there are 10 tonnes of water in the tanker. The tanker then comes to the pier-side device
column5: which has been built as a weighing system. It has active de-watering
column6: by which I mean the fish are tumbled between conveyor belts and a huge fan blows the water off them. The conveyer belt has a grid on it so the water can fall through it. Essentially
column7: the fish will be without water for the few seconds that they are going over the conveyer belt. The fish then go into the pre-charged tanker. The only addition to the tanker from its first weighing is fish. That tanker goes over the weighbridge
column8: the first weight is subtracted and a further 2% is taken off that figure to account for any residual water that might be in the gills of the fish
column9: or anything like that. That gives an accurate weight of fish. The Deputy asked if we are creating an onus. The answer is "No". The first tanker comes pre-charged and the second tanker can get its water from the water that was with the first tanker’s fish. It can be diverted one way and then the other. The other question was whether we are creating an onus on the vessels. No
column10: the vessels have their refrigerated sea water and refrigerated systems. They have refrigerated sea water. We need to contextualise this. This is 5% and it is a way of unlocking almost 100% weighing at the factory. That is what we are getting to here.

column2: I will point out that Killybegs continued to operate through this period and there were many landings in Killybegs throughout the pelagic season this year. I can give the Deputy statistics about them if he wishes. Regarding fishmeal
column3: the Deputy is right to point out that a lot more blue whiting has gone for human consumption this year and last year. In years past
column4: the bulk of blue whiting used to go for fishmeal. It is welcome to see value being added to this fish and that it is going for human consumption rather than fishmeal. With regard to landings of blue whiting
column5: the catch of 19 out of 20 vessels that land there goes straight to the factory for weighing so the Deputy must take this into account when he describes the situation as dire. What the sector has chosen to do in respect of blue whiting since the requirement came in and the two options became available was divert all the landings that we declared controlled landings into fishmeal. It has taken that option rather than using either of the two options for pier side weighing and having this fish used for human consumption. I hope we can avoid this situation going forward because the more of this fish that is used for human consumption
column6: the better. Deputy Pringle referred to the extra value to the fishermen if it goes into human consumption. I agree with that. column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-05-18 00:00:00	Weighing of Fisheries Products: Discussion	376	I can certainly have a go at the first part of the Vice Chairman's question but

column3: I am puzzled as to why it was not picked up and acted on. The bigger picture is as I outlined earlier
column4: that is
column5: that we have a number of fish stocks off our coast. We are lucky to have the richest fishing grounds in Europe. Those stocks are assessed scientifically to establish what the outtake from them can be. That sets a limit and feeds into the quota management
column6: which is the business of the Minister. Quotas are distributed and vessels go out to fish. That is where the SFPA comes into this. Vessels go out
column7: they fish those stocks
column8: they land and we meet them at the quayside. Nineteen out of 20 of them will go to the factories and will weigh what they have there. I am talking about bulk pelagic fisheries now: mackerel
column10: herring and blue whiting. Nineteen out of 20 will go straight to the factory because we have a control plan in place that allows for weighing in the factory. On the basis of those 19 landings going to the factory
column11: one out of 20 has to be weighed under our supervision at the pierside. Those fish are transported in bulk tanks containing refrigerated seawater that is chilled down to preserve the quality of the fish. The vessel pulls up to the quayside and those fish get pumped into the pierside device
column13: to all intents and purposes - I am sure Deputy Mac Lochlainn has seen it - a hopper and a conveyor belt system that carries the fish up the conveyor. As he pointed out
column14: there is a facility to weigh on it
column15: a continuous belt weigher. In option 1 we do not use that weighing facility; we just use the conveyor portion of it to convey the fish into a tanker that is waiting under that machine and that has been pre-charged with refrigerated water and weighed on a weighbridge
column16: so we have a weight for the tanker and the water. The fish is added and the tanker with the water and the fish goes back over the weighbridge again. It is weighed again. One weight is subtracted from the other to give a very accurate weight for the fish. The fish then go to the factory for processing.
